content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several tissue fragments, likely from a lymph node dissection. There are at least three large, well-circumscribed, basophilic structures consistent with lymph nodes. Additionally, there are a few smaller, more irregular tissue pieces, including the one at the top left. The tissues are embedded in adipose tissue.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

This is the first tissue fragment at the top left of the slide. As a pathologist, it is crucial to examine every piece of tissue to identify all potential lymph nodes, regardless of their size or shape. This fragment is small and has an irregular contour, warranting a closer look to confirm if it is a lymph node and to begin the search for metastatic cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is one of the larger, more structurally intact lymph nodes, making it a good starting point for a systematic evaluation. At low power, this lymph node shows a mottled or heterogeneous appearance, with both dark purple lymphoid areas and lighter pink areas. This pattern requires closer inspection to differentiate between benign reactive changes (like prominent germinal centers or sinus histiocytosis) and the presence of metastatic tumor deposits, which often appear as eosinophilic (pink) nests of cells within the lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, it is crucial to examine every single piece of tissue on the slide, regardless of its size. This small, isolated fragment, located to the right of the larger lymph nodes, must be assessed. It could represent a tiny lymph node completely replaced by tumor, a satellite tumor deposit, or a fragment from the primary tumor. Its distinct nature from the larger nodes makes it a point of interest for careful evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for these lymph nodes is to search for metastatic cancer cells. I would systematically examine each lymph node section. The green box is placed on the third major lymph node from the left. I am zooming into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of the node, near the subcapsular sinus, which is a common initial site for metastatic deposits. Even at low power, there might be a subtle irregularity or architectural distortion in this region that warrants closer inspection to rule out or confirm the presence of tumor cells infiltrating from the sinus into the lymphoid parenchyma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node to screen for metastasis. The zoomed-in area corresponds to the largest lymph node on the left side of the image. It's a logical place to start the evaluation to assess the overall architecture. The primary goal is to scan the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for any non-native cell populations, such as clusters of atypical epithelial cells or glandular structures that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a fragment of lymphoid tissue, confirming it is part of a lymph node. It consists of a dense population of small lymphocytes. Some dark pigment (likely anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin) is present in the subcapsular region. There are no atypical epithelial cells or glandular structures to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a fragment of a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. There are multiple lymphoid follicles, some appearing reactive with germinal centers. The lighter pink areas correspond to expanded sinuses containing numerous benign histiocytes (sinus histiocytosis). Additionally, there are scattered deposits of black, granular material, which is anthracotic pigment (carbon), commonly seen in mesenteric lymph nodes. I do not see any atypical cells, malignant glands, or cohesive nests of carcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that of a reactive lymph node with sinus histiocytosis and anthracosis, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a piece of tissue with black ink on one edge, which is used for marking margins. The tissue itself is not a normal lymph node. It is infiltrated by atypical glands and nests of malignant epithelial cells, consistent with adenocarcinoma. There is a surrounding desmoplastic stroma and a significant inflammatory infiltrate. My impression is that this is a fragment of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The absence of discernible residual lymph node tissue would raise the possibility of this being classified as a tumor deposit, which has prognostic significance.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes within a lymph node. On the far left, there is some perinodal adipose tissue and black pigment (anthracotic pigment or tattoo ink from a prior colonoscopy). I am carefully searching for atypical cells, such as large cells with irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, or the formation of glandular structures, which would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. However, in this specific field of view, I do not see any convincing evidence of malignant cells. The tissue appears to be composed of benign, reactive lymphoid tissue. My impression is that this particular area is negative for metastasis, and the zoom was performed to confirm the absence of tumor.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals the internal architecture of the lymph node. I see numerous lymphoid follicles, many of which contain prominent, pale-staining germinal centers, indicating follicular hyperplasia (a reactive process). The interfollicular areas are populated by small lymphocytes. There are also some dilated sinuses and scattered dark granular pigment, likely anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin. Critically, there are no visible nests, glands, or single atypical cells to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
